author: Corilyn Shropshire
title: Nonprofit to help low-income youths land jobs at banks - Chicago Tribune
text:
A Los Angeles-based nonprofit is launching a free local training program to prepare and place eligible Chicago-area residents in banking industry jobs.
BankWorks said it will expand its eight-week training program to the Chicago area next year. The program, funded in part by U.S. Bank, Wells Fargo and Bank of America, places low-income young adults in bank jobs that include teller, personal banking and customer service.
"These aren't just any jobs, they're steppingstones to rewarding careers," said Colleen Anderson, executive director of BankWorks.
"The BankWorks training and job placement program nurtures and trains talent that we can tap into, creating a win-win situation for us and the local community," said Julie Chavez, senior vice president at Bank of America and local market manager in Illinois.
Once BankWorks selects the local vocational groups and workforce training centers it will partner with, the program will run eight classes with 25 to 30 participants four times per year, Anderson said.
During the training, participants will learn a mix of hard and soft skills, from issuing a cashier's check to how to dress on the job, Anderson said. "We provide a good, solid, fundamental base of knowledge and skill so that they go into the (bank), speak the language and understand what's expected," she added.

(Becky Yerak) Participants also have access to mentors and tutors for coaching and to help them hone specific skills. Participants must have a high school diploma or GED to apply for the program once it is available.
After the training, participants attend a job fair where each of the funding banks interviews them for a potential job. Nationally, BankWorks aims to place their 1,000 t h graduate before the end of this year.
U.S. Bank, Wells Fargo and Bank of America have each pledged $1 million over five years to support the rollout of the program that already operates in Seattle, San Francisco, Phoenix and Portland, Ore. The Sheri and Les Biller Family Foundation also pledged $1 million.
Anderson said BankWorks' graduation rate is 75 percent, and 71 percent of graduates have landed jobs.
